explanation:
The correct calculation converts weeks to days (10×7) then days to hours (×24), totaling 10×7×24.  
The student performed 10×7×12, indicating they multiplied days by 12 instead of 24.  
The error stems from using 12 hours/day rather than 24. This reflects confusion between the 12-hour clock cycle (AM/PM periods) and the full 24-hour day.  
The misconception directly substitutes half the correct hourly conversion, as the student likely conflated "12-hour segments" with total daily hours.  
This differs from thinking there are 7 hours/day (which would produce 10×7×7) or 60 hours/day (which would use ×60).  
The student’s arithmetic was correct, so the flaw lies entirely in the conversion factor, not calculation errors.
